Posts.Content: Hi Ida Many thanks for your message. I’ve been told how rare occult breast cancer is so it’s very good to hear that you’re doing well and all clear.  I have finished chemo - in fact I was so ill with my last cycle in February that the oncologist agreed that I could skip the final planned cycle. My scans after 6 cycles were good and I had surgery just over a week ago - the same as you, axillary node clearance on the left side.  I’ve tried to stay positive all the way through but I’ve had some desperate days, I must admit. My main issue is that feeling, just like you say .... it must be somewhere else in my body. My scans were all clear though, so I know it’s not rational .... except that I never would have known I had this without a very good routine mammogram w.hen I hit 53! The lymph node initially identified was right up against my chest wall, so it was hidden deep within my breast, with no outward signs at all.  Scary really, as even for surgery last week it had to be ‘tagged’ first with a clip, then a wire, backed up by further mammograms, so that the surgeon made sure he got it. I have a great team of breast care nurses, oncologists, surgeons, etc so I’m confident that I’ve had the best possible treatment. I get my histology results next week, then it’s radiotherapy and probably Tamoxifen to follow.  I’m trying to take this one step at a time but I can’t help having that nagging worry in my mind that I was lucky this was even picked up. I’m told there’s very little research about occult breast cancer. My surgeon reassures me that the axillary node clearance will do the job, and that women who’ve had the same treatment have done very well, so I’m incredibly pleased that you got in touch and are proving her right!! I’m glad to say I appear to be healing up well, although it’s all still pretty sore of course. The best thing is that I’m able to eat properly again! Like you I ate whatever took my fancy during chemo, including rather too many chocolate biscuits ...  I’m trying to eat healthy meals again now, as otherwise I’ll turn into a blob!  Many thanks again for your encouraging words.  Sara
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Many thanks for your comments. Your words echo those of my friend who has been through this a few years ago. Some days it’s just hard to hang on to the positives! Hopefully today will be a better day.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Thanks for your reply. Sounds very similar to me except the treatment is different. I’m on chemo first, then due for surgery and RT. It’s the latest change of chemo that’s floored me but I’m hanging in there trying to remind myself that it’s temporary and I’ll have finished all treatment by the summer! I don’t know what will happen after that but Tamoxifen has been mentioned. Hope your chemo goes ok.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi After a routine mammogram (I’m 53) I was diagnosed with primary occult breast cancer on Friday 13th October last year. I’m told that breast cancer appears like this rarely - in about 0.1% of patients. Basically I have several enlarged lymph nodes with the largest about 10mm, which I’m told is ‘not big’. I had every test and scan going but there are no tumours in my breast at all. I’ve had 3 cycles of Taxol (Paclitaxel) but had to skip the 4th as I had such bad problems with my hands and feet. So I had my first EC Therapy last week and since then I’ve felt awful. Just wiped out with nausea and fatigue, plus now I’m feeling shaky all the time. I’m normally the sort of person rushing about, never sitting still, and I have a teenage son with mobility difficulties who I look after. So sitting around doing nothing is weird for me. My boss has been great (I teach Law one night a week) and even though I’ve done work from home for cover tutors I’m desperate to get back to teaching. I just don’t know how I’m going to manage on the new chemo and feel like I’m letting my students down.  After chemo (3 more EC planned!) I’m up for axillary node clearance, then radiotherapy. Frankly I don’t know what to dread more - the ongoing nausea or the surgery?! I have great family and friends, a husband who is holding it all together for all of us, and a fab medical team, so I feel lucky. I try to pick out the positives/silver linings in everything to do with this rollercoaster journey BUT I still feel alone plus I have days like today where I’m not holding it my s**t together at all!  So I’m just reaching out to anyone out there who feels the same, or who has come across occult breast cancer, or who has advice or thoughts to share! Thanks.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi Our journeys sound very similar  - I was diagnosed a year ago (Fri 13th!) due to one enlarged lymph node near my chest wall, so it was buried pretty deep. I had no visible signs at all of cancer, and no tumours. I had chemo, then axillary node clearance (10 out of 18 had cancer in, so similar proportions), then radiotherapy. I’m having similar issues with Letrozole but I’ve just started acupuncture to try to help with sweats, aches and insomnia, as my oncologist said it’s helped some other women. I’m also taking sage tablets again, which I was taking pre-cancer for menopausal symptoms!! MRI is due soon and mammogram is all done, so it’s just waiting for results now. I did opt for the biophosphonates as frankly I’ll grab on to anything that might help and we have a family history of osteoporosis so I’m concerned about that too. However, in your shoes I probably would have said no.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Thanks Deb I had my 4th chemo last Tuesday. The first 3 were reasonably manageable but they changed me to EC therapy last week and I’ve had a bad time with nausea. However, I’ve been told, and as usual I didn’t pay proper attention, that everyone is affected differently. I waited far too long to get help with the nausea and ended up back at hospital today on fluids and new anti-emetics. Some people have worse side effects than others, some have very few. We are all different and the oncologists will help and try to personalise your treatment and medication to suit. Chemo can be hard but you need to ask for help if it gets tough. My friend keeps telling me that it’s killing off the sneaky cancer so it’s doing me good. Not always easy to remember, I know, but hopefully you won’t have too much trouble with side effects! Good luck with it all. We’re in this together so come back with your news!! X
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hey there. Footloose is all done (I came in on the end of it so not sure I completely got it!!) so we’ve started on a bit of Justin Timberlake - Can’t stop the feeling! Lovely! I’ve just joined but I think it’ll be good for the soul x
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi, and thank you for your post. I’m doing well, I think! I’m a year down the line. Active treatment is done and I’m just chucking down the Letrozole every day, plus having Zometa infusions every 6 months. I’ve started Parkrun every week and I’m losing weight, plus I’m just joining my local Rock Choir!! I’m in a new job. I have new, grey curly hair. All in all I’m not bad. Obviously I have the odd wobble but the breast clinic always check me out and support me. Just had my first mammogram and I’m due an MRI aswell because I’m so unusual- fingers crossed!!! It’s good to know I’m not alone, so I hope you continue to do well. Thanks for getting in touch.
Posts.Title: Primary occult breast cancer - anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi Having read these posts I finally feel I’m not alone. I was diagnosed with primary occult breast cancer on Friday 13th October - really you couldn’t make it up. This means it has metastasised into my lymph glands but they can’t find a primary tumour. Literally it’s not appearing anywhere. This all came from a routine mammogram. I’ve had all the tests and it hasnt spread although there’s something in my lung so small they can’t identify. A second breast biopsy last week may reveal more this week but it’s been a waiting game and the uncertainty is awful. The first two weeks were the hardest. I’m trying to laugh and joke about it but I still don’t have a treatment plan. Chemo looks like a certainty but the rest isn’t confirmed yet.  My husband has truly stepped up. Plus my two children have been great. I’m only just able to talk without crying though. My best friend has been through all this and come out the other end fit and well but it’s so hard to put it to the back of your mind. Does everyone else wake up thinking about it??
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi there!  I’m so glad it’s not just me - although obviously I wouldn’t wish this on anyone! My breast care nurse has been doing her job for 10 years and said she’s only had 2 women with occult breast cancer. My consultant was the same. The only up side seems to be that it’s clearance of lymph nodes and not mastectomy! I am told that results are just as good without mastectomy so they won’t suggest that unless something nasty surprises us all. I don’t know yet whether mine is oestrogen based or genetic but my mum had breast cancer 34 years ago so they’ll do the test soon. When do you start chemo? I’m having chemo first then surgery later. Good luck with it all. I hope you have lots of support around you x
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks for your reply ronstar. I saw my consultant and her amazing team yesterday. They gave me options but we agreed with their recommendation- chemo, then surgery, then radiotherapy. I have the rather rare primary occult breast cancer. It’s in 2 visibly enlarged lymph glands but there’s no visible tumour. The largest one is marked now so that they can monitor the response to chemo (6 lots probably). Surgery may only be stripping out lymph glands and if they shrink that will make surgery less. If any surprises appear then I could still have a mastectomy but that looks unlikely, which is something! Of course I’m not looking forward to it all but having a plan is somehow reassuring. I can joke and laugh most of the time but at night I do sometimes lie awake churning it all over. I’m suffering with anxiety particularly in the mornings, but the breast care nurse said she thought I’d be odd if I wasn’t.  So it’s oncology next week with any luck and then I’ll have more details. We are exhausted with talking about it but I’m fortunate to have a few great friends to walk with me through this journey.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi There’s not much info available but I was told that only 0.1% of breast cancer patients present as occult. My consultant mentioned an American study involving just over 50 women which started in 1975 and completed I think in 2015 (!). Her point was that mastectomy is not any more effective than lymph node removal - the study showed that in 90% of women with this presentation they did just as well (is no relapse or recurrence) without mastectomy as with it. I’m having chemo first to watch how effective it is on the enlarged nodes, and with the hope of minimising surgery. The study helped the MDT make its recommendations about my treatment apparently. I hope that helps!
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer
